title: ‘I would join a boycott’: Why readers oppose Market Basket’s firing of Artie T.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Market Basket's board fired CEO Arthur T. Demoulas after months of tension and accusations of non-cooperation.
Over 2,500 Boston.com readers responded, with 86% opposing the firing and 61% planning to boycott Market Basket.
Readers expressed loyalty to Demoulas, crediting him with Market Basket's success and fearing changes under new management.

title: Boston City Council shows mixed support for rent control ballot question
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston City Council shows mixed reactions to a 2026 rent control ballot proposal, with discussions temporarily halted.
Councilor Henry Santana filed a resolution in support of the ballot, but objections led to its referral to a committee.
Rent control would link annual rent increases to cost of living, capping increases at 5% with specific exemptions.

title: Haim praises Brick Street Bagels: ‘Bomb bagels’
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Haim praised Brick Street Bagels, calling them 'amazing' and 'bomb bagels' after visiting the shop during a stay in Boston.
Brick Street Bagels, founded by Jordan Renouf in 2022, plans to open a permanent location in South Boston this year.
The bakery is known for its fresh, crunchy bagels and previously operated pop-ups in South Boston, South End, Cambridge, and Beacon Hill.

title: Thieves in Quincy are ordering pizzas then stealing the driver’s car, police say
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Two pizza delivery drivers in Quincy had their cars stolen during bogus delivery orders, police report.
Thefts involved masked individuals in dark clothing who stole cars once drivers approached delivery locations.
Recovered vehicles in Brewer's Corner and South Shore Plaza; arrests made in unrelated car theft incident.

title: Man allegedly made bomb threats to Everett city councilor
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Scott Merchant, 36, of Salisbury, pleaded not guilty to making bomb threats against an Everett city councilor.
FBI and Salisbury police worked together to arrest Merchant following social media threats involving firearms and explosives.
Merchant is charged with bomb/hijack threats and will have a court hearing Thursday to determine bail eligibility.

title: Here’s why there are American flags above gates B32 and C19 at Boston Logan Airport
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: American flags at gates B32 and C19 at Logan Airport honor the 9/11 attacks' victims.
Flags were first raised weeks after 9/11, marking departure points of hijacked flights American 11 and United 175.
Additional flags now fly over gates B11 and B27 due to terminal changes, keeping the memory alive.

title: MassINC poll: Just over half of voters approve of Healey’s performance
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: 56% of Massachusetts residents approve of Gov. Maura Healey's performance according to a MassINC poll.
Healey's approval is highest among Democrats, college-educated voters, and women over 50.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s performance as HHS Secretary disapproved by 56% of surveyed Massachusetts residents.

title: Where to find college student discounts in Greater Boston
author: Frances Klemm, Nia Harmon and Laura Emde
bullets: Students receive discounts at major Boston venues like the Boston Symphony Orchestra and Museum of Fine Arts with a valid ID.
Special student pricing is available at AMC Theatres, ArtsEmerson, and Coolidge Corner Theatre for discounted movie tickets.
Boston Bruins and Red Sox offer student-priced game tickets, with select Bruins games starting at $60 and Red Sox games at $9.

title: ‘It’s a cornerstone of who we are’: Read Rep. Lori Trahan’s letter to Market Basket board
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: U.S. Rep. Lori Trahan expressed disappointment over Arthur T. Demoulas's removal as CEO of Market Basket.
Market Basket board removed Demoulas amid a feud with his sisters controlling the company's majority stake.
Trahan praised Market Basket's community value and urged the board to honor this legacy in future decisions.

title: What Jabrill Peppers said about his surprising release from the Patriots
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Jabrill Peppers, 29, was released by the Patriots after signing a contract extension last year and has joined the Steelers.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel cited team interests for releasing Peppers, who was missed most of last season due to legal issues.
Peppers aims to quickly adapt to Pittsburgh's defense, viewing the team as a good fit due to its defensive tradition.
